text: we have 11 million people living
illegally in this country 11 million
undocumented immigrants we don't have
the capacity to deport 11 million people
eleven million undocumented people
currently live in the United States
here's a look at who they are according
to the Department of Homeland Security
majority have been here for more than
ten years
54% 6.1 million arrived between 1999 and
2004 61% are between the ages of 25 and
44 and overall it's about 50/50 men and
women the Pew Research Center estimates
four million have children born here in
the United States these people are among
the five million expected to receive
protection from deportation and
permission to work legally but not full
citizenship under President Obama's
executive action everybody agrees that
our immigration system is broken
most states with the largest populations
are also home to the most undocumented
people California has two point four
five million followed by Texas Florida
New York New Jersey and Illinois but
Nevada has the largest percentage of
illegal immigrants meanwhile immigrants
are settling across the country now with
populations rising in Maryland where
there is near universal health care in
DC to Pennsylvania Virginia and Nebraska
which each offer growing economic
opportunities immigration makes America
stronger immigration makes us more
prosperous nearly all men here without
papers 87% are working most women 82%
are also employed or home caring for
children the construction industry has
long been a source of jobs for the
undocumented now southeastern states
with expanding metropolitan areas like
Nashville Tennessee and Charlotte North
Carolina are newly attracting immigrants
and finally a few interesting thirds to
note a third of undocumented adults live
below the federal poverty level but also
nearly a third own homes and a third
carry health insurance overall the vast
majority 5.8 million are Mexican born
while the number of people coming from
Mexico is declining the numbers seeking
refuge from gang violence in poverty in
Guatemala El Salvador and other Central
American countries is rising
but unless these people have been here
for more than five years and have
us-born children they're unlikely to be
protected by President Obama's
immigration plan
